summary: The paper describes the synthesis of β-branched α-amino acids using chemoenzymatic methods, including Suzuki couplings. Enzymes such as Trigonopsis variabilis D-amino acid oxidase are used in the process.
key_claims: Suzuki couplings were performed using vinyl iodide and various boronic acids.
The yield of (Z)-2-Acetylamino-3-phenyl-but-2-enoic acid methyl ester was 81%.
Enzymes like Trigonopsis variabilis D-amino acid oxidase were used in the synthesis.
_title: A Versatile Chemoenzymatic Route to Enantiomerically Pure β‐Branched α‐Amino Acids.
_abstract: IR absorption spectra were recorded on a Jasco-FT/IR-410 Spectrophotometer using standard techniques. 1 H and 13 C-NMR spectra were recorded on a Varian Gemini or Bruker AC250 spectrometer. Chemical shifts are reported in ppm. Mass spectra were recorded on a Micromass Platform-2 under electrospray conditions or Magnetic Sector MS250 machine for FAB-MS. Analytical normal phase HPLC was performed on a Chiracel OD-H column eluting with 1ml/min 5% IPA in Hexane at 210nm at 10°C. Reverse phase HPLC was performed on a Chirobiotic T column eluting with 0.7ml/min 40% ethanol in Water at 210nm. Peak intensities are reported to an accuracy of 0.1%. Optical rotation was measured on an AA1000 polarimeter from Optical Activity Ltd (measurements made at the sodium D-line). Concentrations are given in g/100ml. Column chromatography was carried out using Fisher silica 60A, particle size 35-70 micron). Melting points were carried out on a Gallenkamp melting point apparatus with no corrections. All solv
